importance: This paper is crucial for researchers in outlier detection due to its novel approach to handling high-dimensional data with multiple views.  **GSAAL offers a scalable and effective solution**, addressing limitations of existing methods and opening new avenues for research in this vital area of data mining. Its superior performance and mathematical formulation will significantly impact the field.
summary: Generative Subspace Adversarial Active Learning (GSAAL) excels at outlier detection in high-dimensional, multi-view tabular data by using multiple adversaries and a generator to learn inlier distributions across subspaces.
takeaways: GSAAL effectively addresses the challenges of inlier assumptions, curse of dimensionality, and multiple views in outlier detection.
GSAAL demonstrates superior performance compared to existing methods, especially in scenarios with multiple views.
GSAAL provides a scalable solution with linear inference time, making it suitable for large datasets.
tldr:
Many unsupervised outlier detection algorithms struggle with high-dimensional data, particularly when dealing with multiple views (MV) or making assumptions about inliers. These issues lead to inaccurate outlier identification and limited scalability.  This paper introduces a novel approach to outlier detection that directly tackles these issues.
The proposed method, Generative Subspace Adversarial Active Learning (GSAAL), uses a generative adversarial network (GAN) with multiple adversaries, each focused on a different subspace. This allows GSAAL to model the inlier distribution effectively across multiple views while being robust to inlier assumptions and high dimensionality.  Extensive experiments show GSAAL's superiority and scalability compared to existing methods.
